    <!-- PlaceHolder tag prevents inline radmenu.ClientID code below clashing with Utility.EnsureScriptManager(this); -->
    <script>

        $(document).ready(function () {
            giveAllMenuLinksAUniqueIdentifier();
            $(".rmLink").on("keydown", setSpacebarToOpenMenus);
        });

        function giveAllMenuLinksAUniqueIdentifier() {
            //Give all menu items a unique attribute value so that I can identify them when spacebar is clicked. Same 'menunumber' attribute is set in .aspx code on menu items.
            var index = 0;
            $(".telerik_main_menu li.rmItem a.rmLink").each(function (index) {
                $(this).attr("menunumber", index);
            });
        }

        function setSpacebarToOpenMenus(e) {
            //Open submenus on spacebar press. 
            var theKey = e.which;
            if (theKey == 32) { // 32 is keycode for spacebar. 
                var menuNumber = $(this).attr("menunumber");
                var menu = $find("ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl01_radmenu");
                var menuItem = menu.findItemByAttribute("menunumber", menuNumber);
                var submenuItems = menuItem.get_items();
                if (submenuItems.get_count() > 0) {
                    if (menuItem.get_isOpen() == false) {
                        menuItem.open();
                        e.preventDefault();
                    };
                };
            };
        };

        function ClickItem(menu, args) {
            //Event set in OnClientItemClicking="ClickItem";
            //When user clicks (presses Enter key) a menu item, if submenu is not open, then open it; otherwise navigate to the item's link. 
            var item = args.get_item();
            var submenuItems = item.get_items();
            if (submenuItems.get_count() > 0) {
                //If submenu is closed, then open it; otherwise click the menu item link. 
                if (item.get_isOpen() == false) {
                    args.set_cancel(true); //Cancel the default click action so that it doesn't trigger the menu item's navigation link.
                    item.open();
                }
                else {
                    if (typeof item.redirectToLink == 'undefined') {
                        item.redirectToLink = true;
                        item.click();
                    } else {
                        delete item.redirectToLink;
                    }
                }
            }
        }

    </script>

role="main"><h1>Permanent Residency</h1><div class="ptl_page"><div class="ptl_col_1"><div class="ptl_portlet_vertical"><div class="ptl_top_portlet" style="display:none;"></div><div id="ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl07_divContent"><div class="entry">
<ul style="margin-top:0in" type="disc">
    <li class="MsoNormal" style="color:#7F7F7F;margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
    mso-list:l1 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:bold;
    mso-bidi-font-style:italic"><a href="#General_Policy">General Policy</a></span></li>
    <li class="MsoNormal" style="color:#7F7F7F;margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
    mso-list:l1 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:bold;
    mso-bidi-font-style:italic"><a href="#preference_categories">Definition of employment-based preference categories</a></span></li>
    <li class="MsoNormal" style="color:#7F7F7F;margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
    mso-list:l1 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:bold;
    mso-bidi-font-style:italic"><a href="#Overview">Overview of immigrant visa application process</a></span></li>
    <li class="MsoNormal" style="color:#7F7F7F;margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
    mso-list:l1 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:bold;
    mso-bidi-font-style:italic"><a href="#Criteria">Criteria for the immigrant visa application process</a></span></li>
    <li class="MsoNormal" style="color:#7F7F7F;margin-bottom:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
    mso-list:l1 level1 lfo1"><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight:bold;
    mso-bidi-font-style:italic"><a href="#Procedure">Procedure for immigrant visa application process</a></span></li>
</ul>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal"><span style="font-size: 14pt; line-height: 115%; color: rgb(64, 190, 160);">&nbsp;</span></strong></p>
<strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">
<h2 id="General_Policy">General Policy</h2>
</strong>
<p><strong> </strong>The University of Illinois at  Chicago will sponsor employment-based immigrant visa petitions (&ldquo;green  cards&rdquo;) for foreign nationals who have appointments at the University,  in conformity with the guidelines set forth below. Both the UIC  appointment and visa assistance will be focused on institutional need. UIC reserves its right to provide employment-based immigrant visa  assistance on discretionary basis.</p>
<p>UIC will consider sponsorship for tenured, tenured track, or clinical  discipline track appointments. In addition, Academic Professional  positions (non-tenure track and non-teaching) will be considered for  immigrant visa sponsorship only when the appointment titles are either  Research Assistant Professor or Research Associate Professor and they  meet the special circumstances as described below in section B of the  criteria. Under exceptional circumstances the Dean&rsquo;s office in  collaboration with the Office of International Services may make limited  exceptions to this policy. Exceptional circumstances are considered to  exist when long-term services of an employee are deemed to be in the  best interest of the University and would serve to further the  University&rsquo;s mission.</p>
<p>No UIC department or individual should promise current or prospective  employees that the University will obtain permanent residence on their  behalf. The decision to file such an application must be made by the  appropriate hiring authority in consultation with OIS. The &ldquo;green card&rdquo;  process is lengthy, involving up to three government agencies, and the  final decision to grant permanent residence must be made at the United  States Citizenship and Immigration Service (USCIS). It is never a  certainty that permanent residency will be approved, and therefore  should not be promised as an enticement benefit for employment.</p>
<p>All costs associated with filing of the employer-based immigrant  petition (I-140) will be paid by the sponsoring department. Under no  circumstances should the foreign national be asked to reimburse the  &ldquo;sponsoring department&rdquo;. Note, it is the beneficiary&rsquo;s responsibility  and at their own expense, to file the necessary documents for adjustment  (I-485) or consular processing.</p>
<p>The Office of International Services is the sole authority for filing  employment-based immigrant petitions, and any other employment-based  petitions on behalf of UIC. Any employment-based petition submitted  without prior authorization and signature of a designated representative  of the Office of International Services may result in a request by UIC  to the government for official withdrawal of the petition. The role of  OIS is limited to those aspects of the document preparation and  submission that are directly related to the University&rsquo;s interests and  related to the University&rsquo;s interests and responsibilities as an  employer.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal"><span style="font-size: 14pt; line-height: 115%; color: rgb(64, 190, 160);">&nbsp;</span></strong></p>
<strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">
<h2 id="preference_categories">Definition of employment-based preference categories</h2>
</strong>
<p>United  States immigration laws provide for three employment-based &ldquo;preference&rdquo;  categories applicable to work at UIC. The purpose of these categories  is to make possible sponsorship of employment for foreign nationals by  the U.S. employers on a permanent basis. These categories define what  must be presented by a sponsoring employer such as UIC to the United  States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) in order to obtain  approval of employment0based immigrant petitions. The OIS will meet with  the foreign national sponsoring UIC department representatives in order  to evaluate the individual&rsquo;s qualifications and the job to be filled,  and thereby determine which of the three categories will be used to  pursue the employment-based immigrant visa. The three available  preference categories are:</p>
<ul>
    <li>First preference (EB-1): Individuals of &ldquo;extraordinary ability&rdquo; or &ldquo;outstanding&rdquo; professors or researchers</li>
    <li>Second preference (EB-2): Holders of advanced degrees or individuals  of &ldquo;exceptional ability&rdquo; (at least 10 years of experience in the field)  in the sciences, arts or business</li>
    <li>Third preference (EB-3): Professionals ( individuals who hold at least a bachelor&rsquo;s degree in the specific field of endeavor</li>
</ul>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal"><span style="font-size: 14pt; line-height: 115%; color: rgb(64, 190, 160);">&nbsp;</span></strong></p>
<strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">
<h2 id="Overview">Overview of immigrant visa application process</h2>
</strong>
<p>An employment-based immigrant visa petition (green card) involves at least a two-part process:</p>
<ul>
    <li>The first part requires the employer to submit to the USCIS an  immigrant petition(I-140) requesting approval under a particular  employment-related preference category.</li>
    <li>The second part is either (a) an adjustment of status application  (I-485) that is processed within the United Stated, or (b) an immigrant  visa application submitted to a designated U.S. Consulate or Embassy  abroad (sometimes referred to as &ldquo;consular processing&rdquo;)</li>
</ul>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal"><span style="font-size: 14pt; line-height: 115%; color: rgb(64, 190, 160);">&nbsp;</span></strong></p>
<strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">
<h2 id="Criteria">Criteria for the immigrant visa application process</h2>
</strong>
<p><span style="font-size: 1.8rem;">The  Office of International Services will use the following criteria when  evaluating requests for employment-based immigrant visa sponsorship:</span></p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>A. Individuals of extraordinary ability or outstanding professor or researcher (First Preference)</strong>
    <ul>
        <li>1. The candidate must be uniquely qualified to fill an identified institutional need.</li>
        <li>2. The educational and experiential qualifications of the individual must be directly related to the field of employment.</li>
        <li>3. The position offered must be &ldquo;permanent&rdquo; as defined by the U.S.  immigration law- term of employment is of indefinite duration, with the  expectation on the part of both employer and employee to extend or renew  appointment/employment agreement upon any expiration date. At UIC,  tenure, tenure-track, clinical tenure-track qualify as permanent.  Appointments as postdoctoral fellows, visiting research specialists,  visiting senior research specialist are considered temporary in nature  and do not qualify for UIC employment-based immigrant visa sponsorship.</li>
        <li>4. Adequate funding (at least 5 years) must exist to support long term employment.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>B. Holders of advanced degrees or individuals of exceptional ability in the sciences, arts or business (Second Preference)</strong>Criteria 1,2,3 and 4 above, plus:
    <ul>
        <li>5. The sponsorship must have a high likelihood of success in meeting  both the U. S. Department of Labor&rsquo;s certification process and the  minimum USCIS criteria for the particular employment-based preference  category.</li>
        <li>6. Documentation that rigorous recruitment efforts ( as defined by  the Department of Labor-i.e. printed advertisements, job announcements,  etc.) were made to fill the position but that UIC was unable to attract a  qualified U.S. citizen or permanent resident to fill the position,  resulting in issuance of &ldquo;labor certification&rdquo; by the U.S. Department of  Labor (if applicable). Note, for new tenured, tenure-track, or clinical  discipline appointments which have teaching responsibilities, the  selection process needs to have taken place within the last 18 months.</li>
        <li>7. Documentation that the foreign national has been in the position  (non teaching and non-tenure track appointments only) for a minimum of  12 consecutive months <span style="text-decoration: underline;">prior</span> to the time of requesting consideration for &ldquo;green card&rdquo; sponsorship.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>C. Professional ( Third Preference)</strong>Criteria 1, 2, 3 ,4, 5, 6 and 7 above, plus:
    <ul>
        <li>8. Demonstrated exceptional job performance by the candidate.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
</ul>
<p><em> Note, all Second Preference and Third Preference cases require  an additional stage in the green card process known as the labor  certification application. OIS will file the required application in the  U.S. Department of Labor&rsquo;s PERM system as part of the immigrant visa  process. However, approval of labor certification must occur prior to  filing of the I-140 immigrant visa petition. </em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center">&nbsp;</p>
<strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal">
<h2 id="Procedure">Procedure for immigrant visa application process</h2>
</strong>
<ul>
    <li><strong>A. Department&rsquo;s Responsibilities</strong>
    <ul>
        <li>1. Identify international employee for sponsorship</li>
        <li>2. Seek consultation with the Office of International Services to determine feasibility and appropriate category</li>
        <li>3. Submit internal request form to the Office of International Services</li>
        <li>4. Agree to assist the Office of International Services during the  permanent residency process (submission of supporting documents,  advertisements, etc.)</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>B. Office of International Services&rsquo; Responsibilities</strong>
    <ul>
        <li>1. Advise departments of feasibility and appropriate category</li>
        <li>2. Review internal request form to determine if it is complete</li>
        <li>3. Submit completed form with OIS recommendation to the appropriate Dean&rsquo;s office for their review and recommendation</li>
        <li>4. Notify the department of the Dean&rsquo;s decision</li>
        <li>5. Complete and submit all appropriate documentation as required by  law as it relates to the appropriate employment-based preference  categories.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>C. Dean&rsquo;s Responsibilities</strong>
    <ul>
        <li>1. Review internal request form received from OIS</li>
        <li>2. Make final determination on UIC sponsorship</li>
        <li>3. Review cases submitted for exception to the policy</li>
        <li>4. Collaborate with OIS and Academic HR to determine if case merits an exception</li>
        <li>5. Submit final recommendation on exception cases to OIS.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
</ul>
</div></div>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="col-md-3 unit col-md-pull-9"><div class="ptl_col_1"><div class="ptl_portlet_vertical"><div id="ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl10_divView">
